title: Forget camping on bridges – these women are the real climate heroes
text:
The eXXpedition crew hope their two-year trip will help to find solutions to the plastic pollution in our oceans (Picture: Exxpedition)

As thousands take to streets with Extinction Rebellion this week to demand action on climate change, a crew of 300 women are setting sail on a two year trip to combat plastic pollution.

The all-female eXXpedition crew begin their Round the World voyage today in Plymouth, Devon, on a research mission to rid the world’s oceans of billions of harmful microplastics.

Their boat will sail through some of the most important and diverse marine environments the world has to offer, crossing four of the five oceanic gyres – systems of circulating ocean currents where plastic is known to accumulate – as well as the Arctic.

During different legs of the two year trip, 300 women will board the 73ft sailing vessel the S.V. TravelEdge.

A ‘core crew’ of four eXXpedition members will be on board for the majority of the mission, including co-founder and scientist Emily Penn.

Advertisement

Emily has been studying plastic pollution for the last 12 years and sailing the world’s oceans with eXXpedition since 2014.

But she said that as concerns over the climate crisis grew, so too did interest in the project’s missions.

Last year, eXXpedition announced it’s Round the World voyage and 10,000 women from across the world applied to join in.

Emily Penn is leading the eXXpedition Round the World voyage (Picture: Eleanor Church/Larkrise Pictures)

The core team will be joined by 300 women from around the world (Picture: Eleanor Church/Larkrise Pictures)

The eXXpedition route (Picture: Exxpedition)

Speaking ahead of the team’s launch in Plymouth, Emily told Metro.co.uk: ‘These women are from all different backgrounds and are not just scientists and climate experts, but really concerned people with different talents and expertise who just want to be able to help.’

She described the 300 as an ‘army of changemakers’ and said that with groups like Extinction Rebellion, climate concerns are being brought to the forefront.

Emily said: ‘I think people are realising that it’s not just down to scientists and law makers, it’s down to all of us to play our part.

‘All of us are responsible and capable of making a difference.

‘I have been studying plastics for 12 years but during a trip we made last summer I collected more plastic than I have ever seen in my life before.’

The crew being made up of women is important as research into plastics being dumped into the ocean has shown the chemicals being released into the sea have a profound impact on female hormones and fertility.

Advertisement

Advertisement

A study in June found the average person eats and drinks at least 50,000 plastic particles each year and breathes in the same amount.

The full extent of the health impacts of ingesting plastic are still not known but research shows some pieces of microplastic are small enough to penetrate human tissues, where they could trigger immune reactions.

Emily said: ‘The first time I started looking at the kind of plastic in the ocean it became clear this is something that affects women’s bodies differently.

‘The plastics we ingest have an impact on our hormones and fertility and whatever we take in we could be passing on to our children.

‘It seemed to me to be quite a woman-centred issue.’

Emily has been studying microplastics in the world’s oceans for 12 years (Picture: Exxpedition)

The mission is aimed at reducing plastic waste and discovering the true extent of the impact of microplastics (Picture: Eleanor Church/Larkrise Pictures)

The team will be made up of novice and experienced sailors (Picture: Exxpedition)

The crew will travel more than 38,000 nautical miles in 30 legs – with their first stop in the Azores in October.

They will be studying microplastics and toxics by day, and holding talks and discussions by night – with the mission aimed at celebrating women in STEM (science, technology, engineering and maths).

It is hoped the women who join the eXXpedition crew will then go back to their respective communities to report back on the research and raise awareness of plastic pollution.

Participants are aged between 18 and 57 and represent over 30 nationalities and include community leaders, academics, artists, filmmakers, business women, psychologists, doctors, actors, activists and sustainability experts.

Advertisement

Emily said: ‘This unique opportunity to build a comprehensive picture of the state of our seas, while conducting much needed research that will inform practical and effective solutions to ocean pollution.

‘We hope we can take a step forward to getting rid of plastic from our seas and their surrounding land.’

The all-female crew will celebrate women in science, technology, engineering and maths during their voyage (Picture: Exxpedition)

The boat sets sail from Plymouth today (Picture: Exxpedition)

description: An all-female crew made up of 300 women today begin a two-year round the world voyage to save the planet's oceans from plastic pollution.
